results.title: Wages policy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Ron Edwards of Melbourne College of Education talks to three prominent spokesmen offering differing views and policy perspectives on wages policy. Interviews with Andrew Hay (Confederation of Employers), John Halfpenny (Metal Workers Union), Kerry Klineberg (Chamber of Manufacturers).

results.title: Policy theories
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Peter Joyce of Melbourne State College presents a detailed look at economic policy including Keynesian, Monetarist, Structuralist and Supply-side theories. For each theory he considers the cause of unemployment and the policy solution; the cause of inflation and the policy solution; conclusions and the major problems of the theory. No other credits.

results.title: Exchange rates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Richard Bluck of Melbourne College of Advanced Education provides an overview of exchange rates. Highlights the background of the current ‘floating of the dollar’ showing alternatives and implications of the decision. Addresses fixed or floating exchange rates, definitions and mechanisms, problems of floating exchange rates, implications for public policy and management of the economy and the Australian experience.

results.title: Vabukori
results.creator_credit: Pilgrim Films and Concept Films of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Economic Change in a Developing Country”
Discusses the socio-economic features of Vabukori, a Mortu village near Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. Traces the migration patterns of the Hula, shows type of community and economy resulting from employment in the town. Considers the future development of such a community.

results.title: Matalau: a Tolai Village in New Britain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economic Change in a Developing Country”.
The last film in the series looks at a highly developed indigenous community - Matalau. Considers the impact Europeans have had on the traditional Tolai culture. Looks at the economy which is based on cash croppage - copra, cocoa, fishing and wage earning; and discusses future development.

results.title: Arou
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economic Change in a Developing Country”.
In this film, a map locates Arou, a tribal area of the Duna people, in the New Guinea highlands between the Central and Muller Ranges. The traditional economy of the people is shown to be almost self-sufficient. Sweet potatoes are the staple food and pigs are the main form of wealth. The lifting of entry restrictions in 1964 allowed European contact to be made with these people and the resulting changes in the economy and some problems now facing the Duna people are revealed. Suitable for Social Studies and Geography. No other credits available.

results.title: Economic change in a development country No.2: Wulukum
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Economic Change in a Developing Country”.
Discusses the socio-economic features of Wulukum, a Sepik village in the Torricelli Mountains, North-West New Guinea The film indicates the geographical location of the Wulukum village in the foothills of the Tarricelli Mountains near the Sepik River. It then shows how the changes have so far, provided little reinvestment of income into the village and that more positive changes will be required to stimulate further economic development.

results.title: Mars the Viking Mission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Looks at the five successful American missions to Mars that have taken place since 1964, discussing how advances in photography have improved scientists’ ability to identify small features on Mars. Also discusses the work performed by two laboratories which have been landed on Mars to analyse soil, test for existence of life and record weather conditions.
